posts.text: - Data WarehousingLearning objectivesâ€¢ Learn how to create a cube and its dependent components in Oracle OLAP, including: Identify and build the dimensions Define measures (both stored and calculated) â€¢ Learn how to map the OLAP model to source data and load data into the dimensions â€¢ Learn how to view the OLAP data o Query through hierarchies o Perform operations like roll-up, drill-down, and pivot â€¢ Understand how data is organized and stored in dimensions and data cubes â€¢ Learn how to query a data cube using SQL queries â€¢ Understand how materialized views are used in cube query optimization Preparation: Data Warehouse Setup Oracle OLAP AWM(Analytic Workspace Manager) é”™è¯¯1ï¼šORA-12560: TNS: åè®®é€‚é…å™¨é”™è¯¯ æ˜¯å› ä¸ºOracleæœåŠ¡æ²¡æœ‰æ‰“å¼€

posts.title: 3-Database
posts.text: é€šè¿‡ set å»ç»Ÿè®¡list ä¸­ä¸åŒå…ƒç´ çš„ä¸ªæ•° Database entity: It is a thing, person, place, unit, object or any item about which the data should be captured and stored in the form of properties, workflow and tables. While workflow and tables are optional for database entity, properties are required (because entity without properties is not an entity) Data linkage: It is a method of bringing information from different sources together about the same person or entity to create a new, richer dataset. - Data LinkageLearning objectives Data Linkage: is a method of bringing information from different sources together about the same person or entity to create a new, richer dataset. â€¢ Learn how to use JDBC/cx_Oracle to interact with Oracle DBMS, including create table, update table, query table, etc. (optional) JDBC: Java Database Connectivity(JDBC) is an application programming interface (API) for the programming language Java, which defines how a client may access a database. It is a Java-based data access technology used for Java database connectivity. It is part of the Java Standard Edition platform, from Oracle Corporation. Oracle DBMSâ€¢ Learn how to measure the performance of data linkage. â€¢ Understand various string similarity measures, e.g., edit distance and Jaccard coefficient, for field-level data linkage. â€¢ Understand the weighted-sum strategy for record-level data linkage. â€¢ Understand the blocking technique used for improving the efficiency of data linkage.Part 2: Measure the Performance of Data Linkagea1. Nested Loop Join for Data Linkage2. Precision, Recall, and F-measure Data Linkage: å¯ä»¥è¢«çœ‹ä½œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ†ç±»é—®é¢˜ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚æ•°æ® r å’Œ sï¼Œ æˆ‘ä»¬é¢„æµ‹ç»“æœè®¾ç½®ä¸º 0 å’Œ 1. å½“ç»“æœä¸º 1 åˆ™æ„å‘³ç€æ•°æ® r å’Œ s æŒ‡å‘çš„æ˜¯åŒä¸€ä¸ªå®ä½“ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯ä»¥è¢«é“¾æ¥ã€‚ æ­£ç¡®çš„æ•°æ®é“¾æ¥ç®—æ³•å¿…é¡»æ»¡è¶³ä»¥ä¸‹æ¡ä»¶ï¼š1) all the linked pairs it predicts are correct2) it can output all possible linked pairs. åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªTaskä¸­ D ä»£è¡¨ç®—æ³•é“¾æ¥çš„ç»“æœï¼ŒDä»£è¡¨æ­£ç¡®çš„é“¾æ¥ç»“æœâ€¢ True positive, if it belongs to both D and D â€¢ False positive, if it only belongs to D â€¢ False negative, if it only belongs to D* â€¢ True negative, if it belongs to neither D nor D* å› æ­¤æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ä»¥ä¸‹å…¬å¼è®¡ç®— precision å’Œ recall ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘› = tp / ğ‘¡ğ‘+ğ‘“ğ‘ ï¼šç†è§£ä¸ºç²¾åº¦ ğ‘…ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘™ = tp / ğ‘¡ğ‘+ğ‘“ğ‘› ï¼šç†è§£ä¸ºå¬å›ä»¥åˆ‡é™¤è‚¿ç˜¤ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼šæ›´é«˜çš„ç²¾ç¡®åº¦é™ä½äº†è¯¯åˆ‡é™¤å¥åº·ç»†èƒçš„æœºä¼š(é˜³æ€§ç»“æœ)ä½†ä¹Ÿé™ä½äº†æ¸…é™¤æ‰€æœ‰ç™Œç»†èƒçš„æœºä¼š(é˜´æ€§ç»“æœ)ã€‚ â€˜â€™â€™è§£é‡Šä¸¤è€…å…³ç³»ï¼Œå¹¶å¼•å‡º F-measureOften, there is an inverse relationship between precision and recall, where it is possible to increase one at the cost of reducing the other. Brain surgery provides an illustrative example of the trade-off. Consider a brain surgeon tasked with removing a cancerous tumour from a patientâ€™s brain. The surgeon needs to remove all of the tumour cells since any remaining cancer cells will regenerate the tumour. Conversely, the surgeon must not remove healthy brain cells since thatwould leave the patient with impaired brain function. The surgeon may be more liberal in the area of the brain she removes to ensure she has extracted all the cancer cells. This decision increases recall but reduces precision. On the other hand, the surgeon may be more conservative in the brain she removes to ensure she extracts only cancer cells. This decision increases precision but reduces recall. That is to say, greater recall increases the chances of removing healthy cells (negative outcome) and increases the chances of removing all cancer cells (positive outcome). Greater precision decreases the chances of removing healthy cells (positive outcome)but also decreases the chances of removing all cancer cells (negative outcome). Therefore,another performance measure, F-measure, was proposed to combine precision and recall by their harmonic mean, as shown below.â€˜â€™â€™F = 2 (precision recall) / (precision + recall) ç–‘é—®Fä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå¯ä»¥ç»“åˆä¸¤è€…çš„ç‰¹ç‚¹-è°ƒå’Œå¹³å‡æ•°â€˜â€™â€™ ####Task2â€”â€”â€”â€”-Answer:â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“eg. â€œThe false positive is the records that appear in both the linkage result and the gold-standard, which is corresponding to count/r esult.size(). There are 120 false positive pairs.â€\ 1) The true positive is the records that appear in both the linkage result and gold-standard, which is corresponding tocount. There are 75 true positive pairs. 2) The false positive and true positive are the records that appear in the linkage result, which corresponding to the len(results). There are 82 false positives and true positive pairs. 3) The true positive and false negative are the records that appear in gold-stand, which corresponding to the len(benchmark). There are 106 true positive and false negative pairs. In this case, precision means the proportion of the pairs that appear in both the results and benchmark in resluts.(è¯­æ³•éœ€è¦æ£€æŸ¥recallè¿˜æ²¡æœ‰å†™) Part 3: Similarity Measures for Field-Level Data Linkageç”±äºåœ¨å¤§å¤šæ•°æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œæ•°æ®åº“ä¸­çš„æ•°æ®æ˜¯å­˜åœ¨é”™è¯¯çš„æ‹¼å†™ã€ä¸è§„èŒƒçš„æ•°æ®ç­‰é—®é¢˜ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦é€šè¿‡è®¡ç®—è®°å½•ä¹‹é—´çš„ç›¸ä¼¼åº¦å»é“¾æ¥æ•°æ®ã€‚è¿™æ¬¡ä½œä¸šä¸»è¦ç”¨äº†ä¸¤ç§æ–¹æ³• Jaccard Coefficient(Jaccard index / Intersection over Union) J(A,B) = |Aâˆ©B| / |AâˆªB| = |{0,2,5}| /|{0,1,2,3, 4,5,6,7,9}| = 3/9 = 0.33.â€¢ A = {0,1,2,5,6}â€¢ B = {0,2,3,4,5,7,9} åœ¨è¿™é‡Œå› ä¸ºæˆ‘ä»¬è¦å¯¹å­—ç¬¦ä¸²æ“ä½œæ¶‰åŠåˆ°äº†é¡ºåºé—®é¢˜ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¯ä»¥é‡‡ç”¨ q-gram çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ 3-gram ä¸‹ â€œpythonâ€ è¿™ä¸ªå•è¯ä¼šè¢«åˆ’åˆ†ä¸ºï¼š pyt yth tho hon å››ä¸ª Task 4 Edit Distancehttps://www.jianshu.com/p/a617d20162cfç¼–è¾‘è·ç¦»æ˜¯æŒ‡é’ˆå¯¹ä¸¤ä¸ªå­—ç¬¦ä¸² A å’Œ Bï¼Œå°†Aè½¬åŒ–ä¸ºB æ‰€éœ€è¦çš„æœ€å°ç¼–è¾‘æ“ä½œæ•°ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­åŒ…æ‹¬ä¸‰ç§ç¼–è¾‘æ“ä½œï¼šâ€¢ Insert a character into a string;â€¢ Delete a character from a string;â€¢ Replace a character of a string by another character.åœ¨å®é™…æ“ä½œä¸­ä¸åŒçš„ç¼–è¾‘æ˜¯å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒæƒé‡çš„ï¼Œåœ¨è¿™æ¬¡å®éªŒä¸­å¯¹æ­¤å¹¶æ— è¦æ±‚ï¼Œæ‰€æœ‰æƒé‡éƒ½è§†ä¸ºç›¸åŒçš„æƒé‡ Data Pre-processing Assignmentâ€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q1 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”- Question - 11.1 -Whatâ€™s mean of Intergrity constraints? Intergrity constraints are a set of rules. It is used to maintain the quality of information. Integrity constraints ensure that the data insertion, updating, and other processes have be performed in such a way that data Integrity is nor effect å®Œæ•´æ€§çº¦æŸæ˜¯æŒ‡ ä¸€ç³»åˆ—çš„è§„åˆ™ã€‚ ä»–æ˜¯è¢«ç”¨æ¥ä¿è¯æ•°æ®è´¨é‡ã€‚ å®Œæ•´æ€§çº¦æŸç¡®ä¿æ•°æ®çš„æ’å…¥ã€æ›´æ–°ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–æ“ä½œä¸ä¼šå½±å“æ•°æ®çš„å®Œæ•´æ€§ã€‚1.2 -What the intergity constraints should primary key follow? 1. No two rows of a table have duplicate values in the specified colun or set of columns. ä¸é‡å¤ 2. The primary key do not allow nulls. ä¸ä¸ºç©º 1.3 Whatâ€™s mean of schema? 1.3 Answer: (1) -The â€˜idâ€™ should be the primary key for Book1. - -No duplicate values and No nulls. (2) - Book 3 - SELECT TOP 100 Title, SalesRank from Book3 ORDER BY SalesRank â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q1 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q2 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-2.1 -Fragmentation strategy http://www.comp.hkbu.edu.hk/~wschow/dd/ch2.html Fragmentation is the task of dividing a table into a set of smaller tables. The subsets of the table are called fragments. Fragmentation can be of three types: horizontal, vertical, and hybrid (combination of horizontal and vertical). Fragmentation å°±æ˜¯å°†ä¸€ä¸ªè¡¨åˆ†å‰²æˆå‡ ä¸ªæ›´å°çš„è¡¨ï¼Œåˆ†å‰²å¾—åˆ°çš„è¡¨å«åš fragmentsã€‚ Fragmentation æœ‰ä¸‰ç§ç±»å‹ï¼šæ°´å¹³ã€å‚ç›´ã€æ··åˆ Oracle æ•°æ®åº“å¯¼å…¥CSVæ–‡ä»¶æ—¶ æ•°æ®ç±»å‹è½¬æ¢ä»¥åŠç©ºå€¼çš„é—®é¢˜â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q2 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q3 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-Lecture 5â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q3 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q4 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-Lecture 6â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q4 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q5 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”- â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q5 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q6 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”- â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q6 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q7 - Start â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-ï¼ˆ1ï¼‰ a. â€œRichmond Shee, Kirtikumar Deshpande and K. Gopalakrishnan;â€ b. â€œK. Gopalakrishnan, Kirtikumar Deshpande, and Richmond Sheeâ€ For these two lists, the content is the same but the order is different. Thus, Jaccard distance is more likely to regard them as similar. Because Jaccard method will split the sting to a set. In this way, the distance between a and b is small.In the contrast, edit distance calculate the distance by the number of steps which include insert,delete,replace. In this way, the distance will bigger because almost words have to be changed. (2) â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Q7 - End â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”

posts.title: 3-Distributed-Computing-AS2
posts.text: ##Essay Format The marks for the sections provide a guide for how long the sections should be. While it is not enforced, having section headings which align to the criterion makes sense (you can add further sub headings as you wish). Clear introduction of the discussed topic - 400 words Discussion of the distributed computing paradigm and/or architecture - 600 words Discussion on issues related to communication, fault tolerance, consistency etc. - 600 words Example applications of the computing paradigm - 400 words-Discussion on issues related to communication, fault tolerance, consistency etc. You need to choose two issues, such as communication and synchronisation. You need to then provide real world examples of how these issues are addressed/implemented. So for cloud computing paradigm you may have something like this (this is only a guide for those who are stuck): Communication in AWS (~125 words) Communication in Azure (~125 words) Synchronisation in AWS (~125 words) Synchronisation in Azure (~125 words)

posts.text: ICE åº”ç”¨ æ‰€æœ‰ICEåº”ç”¨çš„ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥éƒ½æ˜¯ç¼–å†™ä¸€ä¸ªSliceå®šä¹‰ï¼Œ å…¶ä¸­åŒ…æ‹¬åº”ç”¨æ‰€ç”¨çš„æ‰€æœ‰çš„å„ä¸ªæ¥å£ ç¼–å†™æœåŠ¡å™¨å¹¶ç¼–è¯‘ ç¼–å†™å®¢æˆ·å¹¶ç¼–è¯‘ R I (Remote method invocation) communicator adapter -> é€‚é…å™¨ åˆ›å»ºä»£ç†ï¼š stringToProxy(æœåŠ¡å™¨æ ‡è¯†å’ŒæœåŠ¡å™¨ç«¯å£å·) 1234567891011121314151617181920212223242526272829import com.zeroc.Ice.Communicator;public class Server{ private Communicator communicator; public static void main(String[] args) { // åˆ›å»ºå¯¹è±¡ Server server = new Server(); // åˆå§‹åŒ–communicator server.communicator = com.zeroc.Ice.Util.initialize(args); System.out.println("Server starting."); // åˆ›å»ºAdapter å¹¶æŒ‡å®šæ¥å£ com.zeroc.Ice.ObjectAdapter adapter = server.communicator.createObjectAdapterWithEndpoints("SimplePrinterAdapter", "default -p 10001"); // åˆå§‹åŒ–ä¸€ä¸ª PrinterI çš„å®ä¾‹ å«åš object ï¼ˆå®šä¹‰äº Printer.javaï¼‰ com.zeroc.Ice.Object object = new PrinterI(); // ç»™object ä¸€ä¸ªèº«ä»½ -ã€‹ SimplePrinter å¹¶æ¿€æ´» - å¼€å§‹åœ¨ä¸Šé¢æŒ‡å®šçš„æ¥å£ç›‘å¬ adapter.add(object, com.zeroc.Ice.Util.stringToIdentity("SimplePrinter")); adapter.activate(); System.out.println("Adapter activated. Waiting for data."); server.communicator.waitForShutdown(); System.out.println("Server ending"); }} 123456789101112131415161718192021222324252627import com.zeroc.Ice.Communicator;import Demo.PrinterPrx;public class Client{ private PrinterPrx printerWorker; private Communicator communicator; public static void main(String[] args) { //åˆå§‹åŒ–å¯¹è±¡ä»¥åŠcommunicator Client client = new Client(); client.communicator = com.zeroc.Ice.Util.initialize(args); //åˆ›å»ºä»£ç† ä»£ç†æŒ‡å‘è¿œç¨‹æœåŠ¡å™¨çš„ç«¯å£å· å³æŒ‡å®šçš„ adpator com.zeroc.Ice.ObjectPrx base = client.communicator.stringToProxy("SimplePrinter:default -p 10001"); //è¿”å›äº†ä¸€ä¸ª SimplePrinter çš„ä»£ç† client.printerWorker = PrinterPrx.checkedCast(base); if(client.printerWorker == null) { throw new Error("Invalid proxy"); } //è°ƒç”¨äº†æœåŠ¡å™¨çš„æ–¹æ³• client.printerWorker.printString("Hello World!"); }} 123456789101112131415161718public void run() { Thread thread = new Thread() { @Override public void run() { while (bool == true) { SensorData data = getSensorData(); monitor.report(data); try { Thread.currentThread(); Thread.sleep(1000); } catch (InterruptedException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } } } }; thread.start(); } 12345678910111213141516171819private void runMonitor() { String topicName = userName + "Sensors"; com.zeroc.Ice.ObjectPrx obj = communicator.stringToProxy("DemoIceStorm/TopicManager:tcp -p 1000"); com.zeroc.IceStorm.TopicManagerPrx topicManager = com.zeroc.IceStorm.TopicManagerPrx.checkedCast(obj); TopicPrx topic = null; while (topic == null) { try { topic = topicManager.retrieve(topicName); } catch (com.zeroc.IceStorm.NoSuchTopic ex) { try { topic = topicManager.create(topicName); } catch (com.zeroc.IceStorm.TopicExists ex1) { } } } com.zeroc.Ice.ObjectPrx pub = topic.getPublisher().ice_oneway(); monitor = MonitorIcePrx.uncheckedCast(pub);} ###JAVA è¯­æ³•ç§¯ç´¯ï¼š throws (AllSensors.java -> mainå‡½æ•°)2.-LinkedHashMapå¯ä»¥è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯HashMap+LinkedListï¼Œå³å®ƒæ—¢ä½¿ç”¨HashMapæ“ä½œæ•°æ®ç»“æ„ï¼Œåˆä½¿ç”¨LinkedListç»´æŠ¤æ’å…¥å…ƒç´ çš„å…ˆåé¡ºåºã€‚-LinkedHashMapçš„åŸºæœ¬å®ç°æ€æƒ³å°±æ˜¯â€”-å¤šæ€ã€‚å¯ä»¥è¯´ï¼Œç†è§£å¤šæ€ï¼Œå†å»ç†è§£LinkedHashMapåŸç†ä¼šäº‹åŠåŠŸå€ï¼›åä¹‹ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ï¼Œå¯¹äºLinkedHashMapåŸç†çš„å­¦ä¹ ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ä¿ƒè¿›å’ŒåŠ æ·±å¯¹äºå¤šæ€çš„ç†è§£ã€‚ Publish/Subscribe in Ice IceStormï¼š æ˜¯ publish å’Œ subscribe çš„ä¸­é—´å±‚ IceStormï¼š æ˜¯å•å‘é€šçŸ¥æ¶ˆæ¯ component/processï¼š ç”¨æ¥æ˜¾ç¤ºä»è®¢é˜…ä¸»é¢˜ï¼ˆtopicï¼‰æ¥å—æ¶ˆæ¯çš„å…´è¶£ topicï¼š ç±»ä¼¼ä¸ä¹‹å‰çš„Slice interfaceï¼Œ æ¥å£çš„ä¸€äº›æ“ä½œ->å»å®šä¹‰äº†topicæ”¯æŒçš„æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ publisher é€šè¿‡topicçš„ä»£ç†ï¼ˆproxyï¼‰å»å‘é€æ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œsubscriber ç»§æ‰¿topicçš„æ¥å£å»æ¥å—æ¶ˆæ¯ å®ç°å‘å¸ƒè®¢é˜…è€… å…ˆå¾—åˆ° â€˜TopicMangerâ€™ çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜ è·å–å…·ä½“çš„ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚ â€˜Weatherâ€™ ä¸»é¢˜çš„ä¸€ä¸ªä»£ç†ï¼Œå¦‚æœä¸»é¢˜ä¸å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œå°±åˆ›å»ºè¿™ä¸ªä¸»é¢˜ï¼Œå¦èµ°å°±è·å¾—å·²æœ‰ä¸»é¢˜çš„ä»£ç† è·å–ä¸»é¢˜çš„ â€˜å‘å¸ƒå¯¹è±¡â€™ ä»£ç†ï¼Œ è¿™ä¸ªä»£ç†ç”¨æ¥å‘å¸ƒæ¶ˆæ¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¢«çª„åŒ–æˆä¸»é¢˜æ¥å£ æ”¶é›†å¹¶æŠ¥å‘Šç›‘æµ‹æ•°æ® netstat -aon|findstr â€œ8080â€taskkill -PID è¿›ç¨‹å· -F

posts.text: -K-means ç®—æ³• æµç¨‹ï¼š1). éšæœºé€‰å–è´¨å¿ƒï¼Œå¯¹æ ·æœ¬ç‚¹åˆ†ç±»ï¼Œåˆ†ç±»ä¾æ®æ˜¯è·ç¦»Kä¸ªè´¨å¿ƒçš„è·ç¦»ã€‚2). å¯¹ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡åˆ†ç±»ä¹‹åçš„ç‚¹åˆ†åˆ«æ±‚æ–°çš„è´¨å¿ƒ3). å†æ¬¡è®¡ç®—æ‰€æœ‰ç‚¹åˆ°æ¯ä¸ªè´¨å¿ƒçš„è·ç¦»ã€é‡æ–°åˆ†ç±»4). é‡å¤3ã€4 ç›´åˆ°è´¨å¿ƒä¸å†å‘ç”Ÿå˜åŒ– â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-HW4 - Q2â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€” Reconstruction error/ PCAï¼ˆPrincipal Component Analysisï¼‰å¸¸ç”¨äºé«˜ç»´æ•°æ®çš„é™ç»´ï¼Œ å¯ç”¨äºæå–æ•°æ®çš„ä¸»è¦ç‰¹å¾åˆ†é‡ã€‚https://www.chegg.com/homework-help/questions-and-answers/take-dataset-400-points-need-divide-data-2-clusters-using-k-means-consider-one-iteration-e-q48295437

posts.title: Distributed Computing Final
posts.text: General Issues(2016-Q2, 2017-Q1, 2018-Q1, 2019-Q1 ) ä¸»è¦éƒ½æ˜¯Lecture 1 å’Œ Lecture 2 ä¸­çš„å†…å®¹ understand definitions and goals of distributed system åˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç³»ç»Ÿçš„å®šä¹‰æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼ŸA distributed system is a collection of independent computers that are used jointly to perform a single task or to provide a single service. The role of middleware in distributed system (2016-Q2-(a))Answer: Role of middleware is to provide some degree of distribution transparency. Hiding distribution of data, processing and control.
